bibl.title: List of letters and records concerning Roger Post Ames, compiled by Jessie Daniel Ames, 1942

div1.p: This list describes the documents sent by Jessie Ames to Hench concerning her husband, Roger Post Ames. Included in the list are titles and brief descriptions of special orders, letters, photographs, reports, and reprints.

div1.head: List of letters and records concerning Roger Post Ames, compiled by Jessie Daniel Ames, 1942
div1.p:
The portifolio will go out Monday-
Ma.

list.head: Contents
list.item:
Enclosure I (only copies)
1. Special order #47 - A A Surgeon Ames ordered to Santiago, Cuba,
July 12, 1898.
2. Letter - Surgeon General's Office - reporting no vacancy in Army
November 16, 1898 - annulling contract.

Enclosure II (only copies)
1. Special orders #83 - A A Surgeon Ames ordered to report to
Major Walter Reed for temporary duty in Cuba - November 14, 1900.
2. Certificate showing A. A. Surgeon Ames had Yellow Fever February 5, 1901.

Enclosure III (hand written)
1. Letter from Major Reed - March 11, 1901 - thanking Dr. Ames for his
services and asking for Dr. Ames' notes and map for a paper he was
preparing.

Enclosure IV (photostat - handwritten)
1. Letter from Major Reed - March 26, 1901 acknowledging receipt of
map and notes.
2. Letter from Jaor Reed - March 28, 1901 - asking for report of State
Board of Health of Florida.

Enclosure V (only copy)
1. Letter from Colonel O'Reilly - recommending Dr. Ames for Commission
April 15, 1901 - stating Dr. Ames cared for him when he had Yellow Fever.
2. Pictures of Dr. Ames while in Cuba (1900) and as Captain 1901.

Enclosure VI (Original)
1. Letter from R. W. O'Reilly congratulating Dr. Ames on his appointment
as Captain, May 19, 1901.

Enclosure VII (photostat - Handwritten)
1. Letter from Major Reed - May 31, (1901)? congratulating Dr. Ames on
receiving a promotion - recognizing his services.

Enclosure VIII (photostat - handwritten)
1. Letter from Major Kean - September 3, (1901)? asking Dr. Ames to send
Dr. Carroll infected mosquitoes while on leave and asking that this
be kept quiet.

Enclosure IX (photostat - handwritten)
Letter from Major Reed - December 21, 1901 - discusses suspected cases
and announces that Carroll will read last contributions in Chicago.

Who was
DeLong

Enclosure X (original)
1. Letter from Charles DeLong asking help in getting something from the,
December 18, 1901, Government as an experimental case.

Enclosure XI (original)
1. Letter from Charles D. Holliger, lawyer for Private Kissinger,
October 29, 1906, seeking aid in securing pension.

Enclosure XII (original)
1. Letter from John J. Moran (experimental case) asking for statement that
he received no pay for his services as experimental case, March 14, 1907.

Enclosure XIII (only copy)
1. List of fourteen experimental cases.

Enclosure XIV (only copy)
1. List of sixty-three cases treated at Columbia Barracks and Experimental
Camp.

Enclosure XV (originals)
1. Letter from Dr. Guiteras thanking Dr. Ames for mosquito “coop.”
2. Letter from Dr. Guiteras recording data on Dr. Finlay's mosquito theory,
January 13, 1905.

Enclosure XVI (only copy)
1. Letter by Dr. Ames asking for promotion to Major, November, 1901.
2. Second page of letter.

Enclosure XVII (only copy)
1. Last page of letter.
2. Letter by Dr. Ames asking permission to use data on cases December 30, 1901,
treated in Cuba in a proposed book.

Enclosure XVIII (only copies)
1. Transmission of Commission as Captain - January 24, 1902.
2. Transmission of Commission as Major - January 28, 1902.

Enclosure XIX (only copy)
1. Honorable discharge from Volunteer Service - January 9, 1903.
2. Order to Contract Surgeon Ames to proceed to San Antonio for special
duty in re Yellow Fever, Fort McIntosh, September 29, 1903.

Enclosure XX (only copy)
Report (14 pages) to Surgeon General of the Yellow Fever Epidemic at
Laredo, Texas, January 16, 1904.

Enclosure XXI (duplicate)
1. Special Order #173 Contract Surgeon Ames to report for special duty,
Jackson Barracks, Louisiana, in re Yellow Fever Epidemic, July 28, 1905.
2. Telegraphic notice of order #173.

Enclosure XXII (original -handwritten)
1. Letter from J. R. Kean on situation in New Orleans, August 15, 1905.

Enclosure XXIII (original)
1. Letter from General J. M. Lee covering recollections of Yellow Fever
epidemic, New Orleans, 1867.

Enclosure XXIV (original)
1. Recollection of General Lee.

Enclosure XXV (only copies)
1. Letter from Dr. Ames to Surgeon General telling him of map he is
having made, enclosing comparative data on Yellow Fever epidemic
1867 - 1905 - October 10, 1905.
2. Letter from Colonel Maus, saying he is returning map and mentioning
friction at Jackson Barrack - November 16, 1905.

Enclosure XXVI (only copies)
1. Letter from Colonel Maus asking for copy of report and blue print of
map. Yellow Fever at Jackson Barracks and New Orleans, 1905 -
January 10, 1906.
2. Report (without map) of epidemic 1905 - January 16, 1906.

Enclosure XXVII (only copy)
1. Letter from Dr. Ames to Surgeon General Wyman, Public Health and Marine
Hospital Service, October, 1906, asking for appointment in this service.
2. Atatement of record.

Enclosure XXVIII (only copy)
1. Letter to General Wyman giving additional data on, November 8, 1906,
record, giving the names of General O'Reilly and Major Kean - former
Yellow Fever patients of his - as Army references.
2. Order #6 - Granting one month's leave of absence, January 14, 1907.

Enclosure XXIX (copies)
1. Letter from T. D. Berry welcoming Dr. Ames into the Public Health and
Marine Hospital Service, March 20, 1907.
2. Letter from T. D. Berry to Dr. Ames and copy of his letter to Journal
A.M.A. (February 1, 1907) - February 27, 1907.

Enclosure XXX (copies)
Record of Dr. Roger Post Ames prepared from data gathered from -
Enclosures I - XXIV and pamphlets.
1. Etiology of Yellow Fever - Walter Reed
Reprint from Journal A.M.A., Jas. Carroll
February 16, 1901 - A. Agramento

2. Prevention of Yellow Fever - Reed and Carroll
Reprint from the Medical Record -
October 26, 1901

3. Transmission of Yellow Fever - Carroll
Reprint Journal A. M. A.
May 23, 1903

4. Inside History of a Great Medical Discovery.
(Undated and apparently privately printed) A. Agramonto.

Enclosure XXXI (copies)
Record of letters from War Department to -
Mrs. Roger Post Ames, November 19, 1929
Senator Morris Sheppard, January 29, 1930 - February 8, 1930
General William H. Smith, December 12, 1930
Report of Interview between Surgeon General Ireland and Mrs. Ames.
